headline.main: The Best Missions for a Moonshot

docs.abstract: Even if hopes for a "victory" against cancer are unrealistic, how can government best be used to reduce its threat and lethalness?

headline.main: Certain Foods May Lower the Risk of Erectile Dysfunction

docs.abstract: A diet rich in fruits, vegetables, tea and wine may help reduce the risk for erectile dysfunction, a new study found.

headline.main: What’s New in the Dietary Guidelines
headline.print_headline: Guidelines, if Not Clarity, for U.S. Diets

docs.abstract: There’s welcome news for lovers of shrimp, eggs and coffee, but some confusion on fat and conflicting information over meat.

docs.lead_paragraph: PINES-- James M.,a lawyer, economist and international economic development consultant, died on January 10, 2016 in Chevy Chase, MD at the age of 89. He was the son of Samuel S. and Ruth Golden Pines. Pines grew up in Peekskill, NY, and earned a B.A. from Bard College, an M.A. from Harvard, and a law degree from Yale. Over more than three decades as a consultant on nutrition, food aid and program evaluation, Pines undertook assignments with the United States Agency for International Development, the World Bank, and non-governmental organizations in more than 60 countries. Pines' first marriage ended in divorce. Survivors include his companion of 30 years, Janet Lowenthal; his former wife, Caryl Pines Curry; two sisters, Joanne Pines Hersh and Doris Pines Markoff; a daughter, Eve Pines and a son, Roger Pines; son-in-law Richard Martinko; and grandchildren Reed and Irene Martinko. Memorial gifts may be made to JSSA Hospice, 6123 Montrose Rd., Rockville, MD 20852 and to the Robert White Human Rights Fund, Center for International Policy, 2000 M St., NW Washington, DC 20036. A Memorial Service will take place at 12pm on January 27, 2016, at the Wisconsin Place Community Center, 5311 Friendship Blvd., Chevy Chase, MD 20815. 1/3

docs.lead_paragraph: School meals reflect a society’s true food culture, as well as its regard for its children.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by Bettina Elias Siegel takes issue with comparisons between American school lunches and school lunches in other nations, such as one featured in Michael Moore documentary Where to Invade Next; details number of obstacles to healthy, fresh meals being served in schools, from infrastructure to labor costs and dietary prefernces.
docs.snippet: School meals reflect a society’s true food culture, as well as its regard for its children.
